subject: Re: [junit] Re: Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... a simple test seems to indicate no difference using 1.4.1_01-b-1, mixed mode. the times seem the same on a 1 ghz windows box, while the long names seem to
messageBody:
At 09:35 AM 9/24/03 -0400, you wrote:
>On Wednesday, September 24, 2003, at 3:11:08 AM, Chris Dollin wrote:
>It's time for a test.

a simple test seems to indicate no difference using 1.4.1_01-b-1, mixed
mode. the times seem the same on a 1 ghz windows box, while the long names
seem to be a little *faster* on a 350 mhz slak box. maybe i have a bug in
my test :(

public class NameLength {
public static void main(String[] args) {
for(;;) {
int sum=0;
long dt=0l;
s.reset();
for(int i=0;i<n;i++) {
int j=i+1;
int k=j+1;
sum+=i+j+k;
}
dt=s.dt();
System.out.println("short: "+dt+" "+sum);
sum=0;
l.reset();
for(int
iWithAVeryLongNameThatNobodyWouldEverUse=0;iWithAVeryLongNameThatNobodyWouldEverUse<n;iWithAVeryLongNameThatNobodyWouldEverUse++)
{
int
jWithAVeryLongNameThatNobodyWouldEverUse=iWithAVeryLongNameThatNobodyWouldEverUse+1;
int
kWithAVeryLongNameThatNobodyWouldEverUse=jWithAVeryLongNameThatNobodyWouldEverUse+1;
sum+=iWithAVeryLongNameThatNobodyWouldEverUse+jWithAVeryLongNameThatNobodyWouldEverUse+kWithAVeryLongNameThatNobodyWouldEverUse;
}
dt=l.dt();
System.out.println("long: "+dt+" "+sum);
}
}
static final int n=500000000;
static final Time s=new Time(),l=new Time();
}
class Time {
public Time(final long t) {
this.t=t;
}
public Time() {
this(System.currentTimeMillis());
}
public final long reset(final long t) {
final long dt=dt();
this.t=t;
return dt;
}
public final long reset() {
return reset(System.currentTimeMillis());
}
public final long dt() {
return System.currentTimeMillis()-t;
}
public final long dt(final Time time) {
return time.t-this.t;
}
private long t;
}
